Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: COVID-19 Preparedness in Remote Fishing Communities in Rural Alaska
Award.AbstractNarration: This time-sensitive RAPID project focuses on perception of COVID-19 risk in the Bristol Bay region of rural western Alaska. Every spring, the town of Dillingham, the hub of Bristol Bay fisheries, experiences massive in-migration, as an estimated 13,000 workers arrive for the sockeye salmon fishing season. Local health care resources and access to transportation are extremely limited. Leveraging existing partnerships, project investigators will conduct surveys with local residents, decision makers, fishermen and processors to characterize risk perception, evaluate social distancing compliance, and assess perceived costs and benefits of various pandemic mitigation plans. These data will inform epidemiological modeling of possible scenarios in the region and help stakeholders understand the dynamics of COVID-19 in a transient population working in the close quarters of fishing vessels and the crowded conditions of fish processing plants. This project will contribute to the emerging body of research on the perception and effects of COVID-19 across the country, and more specifically, to understanding pandemic impacts on a key Alaska industry.<br/><br/>Standard ethnographic methods, including qualitative key informant interviews, two online surveys, and collection of cell phone mobility data, will be employed to characterize risk perception and response and evaluate compliance with social distancing guidelines. Surveys will be designed collaboratively, and will leverage existing networks developed as part of an ongoing Navigating the New Arctic project (ICER 1927827). Surveys will be conducted at the beginning of the 2020 fishing season and again in February/March 2021. Analysis will evaluate risk perception and response by occupation, socioeconomic status, age, and sex. Epidemiological modeling will be employed to predict disease dynamics (i.e., likelihood of infection and mortality) under different scenarios; these estimates will be used to project demand for limited health care resources in the region, such as ventilators.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the Spring of 2020, local, state, and federal policymakers debated opening the world's largest commercial wild sockeye salmon fishery in Bristol Bay Alaska. Opening the fishery would result in more than doubling the population of a small, isolated region of Alaska, that, as of mid-May 2020, had zero reported COVID-19 cases. Residents of Bristol Bay rely on the fishery as a primary source of income, and for subsistence food harvests, and many remember the devastating impacts of the 1918 influenza pandemic that decimated Southwest Alaska Native populations.

The focus of this project was to collect timely information, provide relevant information to policymakers, and study related research questions using surveys and economic modeling. Project researchers built a structured agent-based model of COVID-19 that reflects the characteristics of the Bristol Bay fishery. For instance, agents in the model include fishermen, processing workers, and townspeople, and locations include communities, households, fishing boats, and processing factories. We then simulated disease transmission with a variety of assumed mitigation policies and analyzed the resulting changes in peak case numbers, daily new cases, and duration of the pandemic. We also estimated potential lost economic activity due to infection to better understand the savings from COVID-19 mitigation policies. Some results of the model were intuitive, for instance, greater interventions reduced transmission and peak case numbers. Also, we found that there are policy tradeoffs in costs and benefits between different types of mitigation policies. These results are described in greater detail in our manuscript "COVID-19 Transmission in a Resource Dependent Community with Heterogeneous Populations: An Agent-Based Modeling Approach," which is currently under review at an academic journal.

We also conducted three large online surveys in 2020 and 2021 with Bristol Bay area residents, commercial fishermen, and processing workers, and we asked survey participants how they perceived COVID-19-related risks and the relative importance of mitigation policies. Over 900 different people participated in our online surveys. Based on survey responses, we found that COVID-19 risk perceptions vary across race/ethnic groups, residency, income, and occupation. Nevertheless, while some respondents indicated perceiving COVID-19 as a serious personal health risk, they chose to continue to work in an environment where the likelihood of exposure to COVID-19 was quite high. These decisions were driven in large part by a lack of alternatives for income and employment. We also found that support for the summer 2020 Bristol Bay area COVID-19 mitigation procedures was significant across fisheries participants and community members. Results from surveys, reported back to local policymakers and other stakeholders, influenced policy. For instance, because of the support for mitigation measures reported by survey participants, one community eliminated a costly tracking system as is described in our 2023 Arctic Yearbook commentary article "Fishing in the time of COVID: Assessing risk in the Bristol Bay commercial salmon fishery and the societal benefits of social science research."

Peer-reviewed articles using survey data and findings from agent-based models are currently under review in different journals and in preparation for submission. Undergraduate students and post-doctoral scholars at the University of Alaska Anchorage assisted with the research.
